ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights RBNZ Rate Decision, Singapore Industrial Production and Fed's Bullard Speech
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US is reportedly considering suspending the next round of tariffs on an additional USD 300bln of Chinese imports while US and China prepare to resume trade negotiations, according to sources familiar with the plans. (Newswires)

US administration official said the goal for US-China G20 talks is to reopen trade negotiations and that it is possible that the sides could agree on no new tariffs as a goodwill gesture, but it is unclear if that will happen. Furthermore, the US is said to be unwilling to give concessions on trade at the meeting and no broad deal is expected, while the official also noted that China's Vice Premier Liu He is still leading the Chinese trade delegation, although new names including possible "hard-liners" may also be in the running. (Newswires)

China’s Premier Li stated that they will reduce negative list on market access as part of efforts to improve the business environment. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

API Weekly Energy Inventories Crude -7.55mln vs. Exp. -2.5mln (Prev. -0.8mln). (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump tweeted that any attack by Iran on anything American will be met with great and overwhelming force and that in some areas, overwhelming will mean obliteration. (Twitter)

US Acting Defense Secretary Esper said the US wants to get on a diplomatic path with Iran and that Iran needs to be held accountable for its actions, while he hopes all allies support any range of activities to deter conflict with Iran. (Newswires)

US Ambassador Wood said we will continue to put maximum pressure on Iran until it changes its behaviour and we will look into what more we can do in terms of sanctions. (Newswires)

Iranian President Rouhani said Iran's armed forces will react decisively and conclusively to any US incursions into their air space, while the Secretary of Supreme National Security Council stated that Iran are to begin the 2nd phase of reducing commitments under the nuclear deal as of July 7th and its Deputy Foreign Minister said the country has no reason left to carry out its nuclear deal commitments unilaterally. Furthermore, there were also comments from a government spokesperson that sanctioning Iran's Supreme Leader is an attack against the nation. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed Chair Powell (Neutral) said many on the Fed see a case for more accommodation but don't want to overreact to single data points, while he noted that rates are low and are likely to remain so. Powell also suggested that in a general matter, it is better to act pre-emptively and not let any economic downturns gain steam, while he sees the market’s tepid inflation expectations as a reason for lowering rates but also repeated it is important for the FOMC not to overreact. (Newswires)

Fed’s Bullard (Voter, Dove) said he does not prefer a 50bps rate cut in July and stated that he voted for a rate cut at the last meeting since inflation is running below target and inflation expectations are deteriorating. Bullard added that by not cutting, the Fed has put higher probability on the July meeting and that he does not like that tactic as he suggested that if the conditions are right today, you should move today. Furthermore, Bullard said that a 50bps cut would be ‘overdone’ but doesn’t want to prejudge the meeting. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (Non-Voter, Hawk) said there are risks the US could talk itself into a recession although he doesn’t see any signs this is happening yet and commented that inflation expectations are very anchored, while Barkin added that he doesn't know if a rate cut or cuts are needed this year and that Fed policy is still modestly accommodative. (Newswires)

US administration official said USD would be less strong and the EUR would be less weak if the Fed took back rate hike from last fall, while the official added that there are many opinions in the White House about the President's authority to demote Powell but also stated that the White House has no plans to demote Fed Chair Powell. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Allergan (AGN) shares soared on after news emerged that AbbVie (ABBV) will buy the co. in a deal worth USD 63bln. Pharma names, including Johnson and Johnson (JNJ), Eli Lilly (LLY), Merck & Co (MRK) and Pfizer (PFE) were all buoyed by the news. However, AbbVie shares sunk. Lennar Corp (LEN) initially moved higher after reporting strong earnings, bringing other housing sector names such as DR Horton (DHI) and PulteGroup (PHM) higher with it; however, negative conference call comments about the outlook/effect of US/China trade tensions, saw the move reverse, with housing names finishing the session in the red. Microsoft (MSFT) moved lower after Jeffries maintained its underperform rating for the technology giant, and cut its PT citing valuation. McDonalds (MCD) shares were supported after Credit Suisse opted to initiate the co. with a buy rating. Kellogg (K) was under pressure after being downgraded at Consumer Edge. Tiffany & Co. (TIF) shares moved lower on a downgrade at Loop Capital. Cloudera (CLDR) saw some upside after Dealreporter reported that the co. could be subject to some activist interest. Medtronic (MDT) moved higher, supported by reports that the co. is considering issuing a jumbo eurobond in Q4 in order to replace its USD debt, taking advantage of near-record low borrowing costs in euro terms. Mosaic Co. (MOS) moved higher after Cowen raised its price target for the co. GrubHub (GRUB) shares popped higher premarket after Citigroup upgraded the restaurant to a buy. Bausch Health Companies Inc (BHC) gained after the health care co. launched its plaque psoriasis lotion. Shopify (SHOP) shares sunk after Wedbush downgraded the co.’s stock to neutral from outperform. FactSet Research Systems (FDS) saw initial upside after the software maker beat earnings expectations, but sunk in later trade. Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) shares rallied ahead of earnings on Thursday, in which the co. is expected to report an increase in quarterly revenue. FedEx (FDX) shares fell after the co. opted to sue the US government, arguing that it should not be held responsible if it accidentally shipped products that violated the recent export ban to some Chinese companies such as Huawei. The move comes ahead of earnings, which it reports after market today (on Tuesday). Tyson Foods (TSN) fell on reports that the US is probing claims that the co. has engaged in poultry price fixing. Wayfair (W) shares plummeted after employees announced a walkout in opposition to furniture sales to migrant detention facilities. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) shares moved after the co. was initiated with an outperform at Credit Suisse. Brighthouse Financials (BHF) shares sunk after the co. was downgraded to neutral at Credit Suisse, who suggested recent drops in interest rates that could reduce distributable earnings. S&P 500 -0.95% at 2917, NASDAQ-100 -1.7% at 7592, Dow Jones -0.67% at 26549.

Yields were lower by 0-3bps across the curve. Attention in early trade was on the 10-year yield, which once again breached 2% to the downside around the cash equity open, as well as the negative US 2-year swap spread, which saw a negative reaction in stocks too. The data slate helped support the complex, after weaker consumer confidence, new home sales missing, and another weak regional manufacturing survey headline (though the internals were more encouraging, with new orders rising). Later in the session, Fed’s Bullard leaned back in the notion of a 50bps rate cut in July, preferring 25bps; markets interpreted this as less dovish than hoped for, which saw yields rise and the USD catch a bid, while stocks slipped. Powell’s comments were balanced, but the Fed Chair offered little to suggest a 50bps rate cut was coming, instead Powell choosing to adopt a more circumspect approach. The US 2-year auction was solid, stopping through the screens, while cover was above recent averages. There was little of note in the bidder breakdown. The US sells 5-year notes on Wednesday; SocGen’s analysts say some concession will be needed ahead of the auction on an outright basis, since current 5-year WI yields are trading below all stop-out rates since September 2017. The banks says that from a relative value perspective, 5s have not got a clear set-up ahead of the auction, and current 5s trade rich vs off the runs in asset swap, though it is slightly cheap on the curve vs 2s and 10s. SocGen says it is neutral on the auction. US T-note futures (U9) settled 6 ticks higher at 128-04.

subject: US MARKET WRAP 25th June 2019: Fed officials lean against 50bps rate cut
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equites lower, Treasuries higher, Dollar higher, Crude flat.
  • REAR VIEW: Balanced Powell circumspect in the face of risks; Bullard pushes back against 50bps cut; US official says aim of G20 is to restart trade talks; Trump says any Iranian attack on US could lead to “obliteration”.
  • COMING UP: RBNZ Rate Decision; German Consumer Sentiment; ECB’s Mersch; BoE’s Carney; US Durable Goods, Advanced Goods Trade, EIA Crude Inventories/Weekly Production.
  • EARNINGS: AMC on Tuesday MU and FDX; On Wednesday, GIS, INFO, GIS.

* FED: Fed’s Bullard (voter, dovish dissenter) leaned back against the notion of a 50bps rate cut at the upcoming July meeting, intimating that the market pricing for rate cuts has gotten a little too far. He justified his call for a rate cut last week on inflation expectations, explaining that this is not a factor that could be resolved by improving trade talks; he also cited the yield curve again. Fed Chair Powell took a circumspect approach in his remarks, repeating that many officials see the case for more accommodation, though do not want to react to single data points, and warned it was [paramount that the FOMC does not overreact. Powell was also upbeat about the economy, noting that baseline outlooks remain favourable against backdrop of heightened uncertainties. However, his comments were characteristically balanced, and on insurance rate cuts, the Fed Chair said it is better to act pre-emptively and not let a downturn gather steam, comments which keep the prospects of looser policy alive. However, Powell did not provide anything specific for the market to suggest a 50bps rate cut was coming, and accordingly, risk assets were on the defensive; particularly since his comments followed (the usually dovish) Bullard, who leaned back on 50bps of cuts, which also followed cautious (in regard to moving too fast) comments from Fed’s Kaplan on Monday (Kaplan also considered slightly dovish).

* FED “INDEPENDENCE”: US President Trump continued to up the pressure on the Fed chair Powell; saying he is "incorrect" that he is entitled to serving a four-year term that expires in 2022 and stated that he thinks he has the power to remove Powell if he wanted to. He did, however, caveat that he currently has no plans to attempt to remove Powell. Later, a US official, voicing the opinion of the President in a familiar criticism, said that if the Fed took back the rate hike from last fall, the dollar would be less strong and the euro would be less weak.

* G20: A Senior US official indicated that the main aim for US/China talks at the G20 summit is for a reopening of trade talks between the two countries, and that there is a possibility that US and China could agree on no new tariffs as a goodwill gesture at the G20 Summit this weekend, although it remains unclear if that will happen. The official said there is a “pretty good chance” for trade talks to restart after the Trump/Xi G20 meeting, although the administration does not expect a broad deal to be made at the meeting (which is largely the market consensus). The official said the US would like to see negotiations return to where they were before talks broke down in May, but the US is not willing to give concessions on trade. Finally, the official added that China's Lui He is still leading the Chinese trade delegation, but new names, including possible trade "hard-liners", may also be in the running. Earlier, China Vice Premier Liu held a telephone call with USTR Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin on Monday at the request of the US, Xinhua reported, laying the foundation for talks between Trump and Xi later this week. The two sides discussed economic and trade issues, and agreed to continue to maintain contact. Meanwhile, markets continue to digest news flow in a cautious manner (both ways), perhaps because the Fed, PBOC and ECB are ready with more liquidity if trade tensions spill over presenting growth risks. No deal is expected this week; instead, a commitment to get talks on track is what the market is looking for.

* CHINESE PRESS’ COMMENTARY: Chinese negotiators will be able to take a tougher line with the US, due to China’s economic resilience, though researchers warned not to go too far in retaliatory measures, since the objective was to bring the US back to the negotiating table, SCMP reported, citing researchers at a Chinese think tank. People’s Daily editorial stated that China has the strength and patience to withstand a trade war, and it could fight to the end if the US persists; the article called on US to show good faith, and take into account US concerns, saying that only equal dialogue can lead to a win/win situation.

* IRAN: Iran’s Foreign Ministry said overnight that the latest US sanctions on its Supreme Leader and other officials means the “closing of diplomacy forever.” US National Security Advisor Bolton, a noted foreign policy hawk, said shortly afterwards that all Iran has to do is negotiate with the US over the nuclear programme, a comment which Acting Defense Secretary Esper later echoed. A US Ambassador said the US will continue to put maximum pressure on Iran until it changes its behaviour, and will look into what more it can do in terms of sanctions (although a majority of Iran’s exports are already under sanctions). US President Trump later took to twitter, and stated that "any attack by Iran on anything American will be met with great and overwhelming force. In some areas, overwhelming will mean obliteration." In regard to the nuclear deal, Iran said on Tuesday it has no reason left to carry it out, and that it has initiated the second phase of reducing commitments; this comes after France, UK, and Germany that there would be consequences if it did not keep to its commitments.

* US ISOLATIONISM: US President Donald Trump has considered withdrawing from a defence treaty with Japan, Bloomberg reported citing sources, as Trump judges the alliance as unfair and too one-sided since it pledges US aid if Japan is ever attacked, but does not require Japan’s military to come to US' defence. Bloomberg noted that Trump has not taken steps towards withdrawing from the treaty, and officials have said such a move is highly unlikely. After Trump’s dovish reaction to Iran downing a drone last week, and then on Monday questioning why the US should be responsible for protecting maritime traffic passing through the Strait of Hormuz, analysts have been taking note of a potentially more isolationist shift from the US President ahead of the 2020 elections.

* CHINA BANKS: A US court has found three Chinese banks in contempt for refusing to comply with subpoenas relating to possible North Korean sanctions violation. Washington Post believes that China’s Shanghai Pudong Development Bank (its ninth largest) is one of these institutions, and is not at risk of being denied access to USD funding, should the US AG decide to do so, which would present perhaps mortal consequences to the bank.

* ECB: ECB's de Guindos said that the overall effect of the bank’s monetary policy (i.e. negative rates) on bank profitability has so far been broadly neutral, but that banks’ profitability prospects could be dampened by deteriorating growth expectations, adding to structural weaknesses.

* RBNZ PREVIEW: The RBNZ is expected to keep the Official Cash Rate unchanged at 1.50%. Given the proximity of last month’s cut, it is likely that the central bank will prefer a wait and see approach whilst recent data also suggests a lack of urgency for further policy loosening. To download the report, please click here.

* US CONSUMER CONFIDENCE: The headline fell by more than expected, to 121.5 (consensus 131.1 from 131.3 revised;  those saying jobs are “plentiful” decreased from 45.3% to 44.0%, while those claiming jobs are “hard to get” rose from 11.8% to 16.4%; thus bringing the gap between Jobs plentiful and Jobs hard to get from 36.3 points to 27.6, which is a negative ahead of the NFP data next week. While 1-year consumer inflation rate expectations rose to 5.1% from 4.6% -- in contrast to the Michigan survey, where inflation expectations collapsed -- it could be indicative that tariff fears were driving the data (US and Mexico tensions were heightened over the survey period, but have subsequently eased after the US refrained from applying sanctions on Mexico over immigration). Now that relations between the US/Mexico have de-escalated, some have suggested we could see a bounce back in the surveys for July.

* US NEW HOME SALES: Missed expectations, printing 626k vs 684k consensus. Pantheon Macroeconomics said the consensus forecast for an increase in sales always looked too high, given the dip in mortgage applications in February (which tends to lead sales by about three months) but this is a bigger drop than we expected: “Note, though, that the margin of error is huge, +/-92K according to the Census Bureau, and we reckon upward revisions are a decent bet,” Pantheon writes, “Either way, a clear rebound is likely in June, and sales then will remain broadly flat until late summer or early fall, when we expect to see new cycle highs.” The consultancy also adds that the 100bps fall in mortgage rates since November is yet to work through, while consumers’ confidence is high and the labour market remains very tight.

* BREXIT: Leading candidate to replace PM May, Boris Johnson, admitted he would need EU co-operation to avoid a hard Irish border or crippling tariffs on trade in the event of no deal, adding that he did “not believe for a moment” the UK would leave without a deal, although he was willing to do so, BBC reported. Johnson reiterated that the deal Theresa May negotiated with the EU was dead. He said he would be able to persuade Brussels to resolve the Irish border issue, saying there were “abundant, abundant technical fixes” that could be made to avoid border checks.

* WTI (Q9) SETTLES USD 0.07 LOWER AT USD 57.83; BRENT (Q9) SETTLES USD 0.19 HIGHER AT USD 65.05: The energy complex traded in a somewhat of a limbo on Tuesday, with the usual suspects of geopolitics and trade concerns providing support and resistance respectively. Iran announcing the “closing of diplomacy forever” and President Trump threatening “obliteration” if the US was attacked was providing justified concerns over supply out of the region. Investors are also tepid ahead of this weekend’s G20 summit, with analysts sceptical on a material breakthrough, with all else remaining could lead to a further deterioration in global growth provided tariffs remain present. It is worth reminding that OPEC+ will be paying close attention to the G20 outcome in how it decides to move forward with production cut extensions, which are widely expected to be rolled over but could be subject to changes in the magnitude of the cuts. The market is also looking ahead to the API’s US energy inventory report after the bell, where crude stocks are seen drawing 2.5mln bbls, distillates building 0.5mln bbls, and gasoline stocks building 0.3mln bbls; Genscape sees Cushing, Oklahoma drawing 165k bbls.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLED 6 TICKS HIGHER AT 128-04: Yields were lower by 0-3bps across the curve. Attention in early trade was on the 10-year yield, which once again breached 2% to the downside around the cash equity open, as well as the negative US 2-year swap spread, which saw a negative reaction in stocks too. The data slate helped support the complex, after weaker consumer confidence, new home sales missing, and another weak regional manufacturing survey headline (though the internals were more encouraging, with new orders rising). Later in the session, Fed’s Bullard leaned back in the notion of a 50bps rate cut in July, preferring 25bps; markets interpreted this as less dovish than hoped for, which saw yields rise and the USD catch a bid, while stocks slipped. Powell’s comments were balanced, but the Fed Chair offered little to suggest a 50bps rate cut was coming, instead Powell choosing to adopt a more circumspect approach. The US 2-year auction was solid, stopping through the screens, while cover was above recent averages. There was little of note in the bidder breakdown. The US sells 5-year notes on Wednesday; SocGen’s analysts say some concession will be needed ahead of the auction on an outright basis, since current 5-year WI yields are trading below all stop-out rates since September 2017. The banks says that from a relative value perspective, 5s have not got a clear set-up ahead of the auction, and current 5s trade rich vs off the runs in asset swap, though it is slightly cheap on the curve vs 2s and 10s. SocGen says it is neutral on the auction.

* S&P 500 -0.95% at 2917, NASDAQ-100 -1.7% at 7592, Dow Jones -0.67% at 26549, SECTORS: Consumer discretionary -1.1%, consumer staples -0.1%, energy -0.8%, financials -0.4%, health care -0.4%, industrials -0.7%, IT -1.8%, materials +0.0%, telecoms -1.6%, utilities -0.6%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Allergan (AGN) shares soared on after news emerged that AbbVie (ABBV) will buy the co. in a deal worth USD 63bln. Pharma names, including Johnson and Johnson (JNJ), Eli Lilly (LLY), Merck & Co (MRK) and Pfizer (PFE) were all buoyed by the news. However, AbbVie shares sunk. Lennar Corp (LEN) initially moved higher after reporting strong earnings, bringing other housing sector names such as DR Horton (DHI) and PulteGroup (PHM) higher with it; however, negative conference call comments about the outlook/effect of US/China trade tensions, saw the move reverse, with housing names finishing the session in the red. Microsoft (MSFT) moved lower after Jeffries maintained its underperform rating for the technology giant, and cut its PT citing valuation. McDonalds (MCD) shares were supported after Credit Suisse opted to initiate the co. with a buy rating. Kellogg (K) was under pressure after being downgraded at Consumer Edge. Tiffany & Co. (TIF) shares moved lower on a downgrade at Loop Capital. Cloudera (CLDR) saw some upside after Dealreporter reported that the co. could be subject to some activist interest. Medtronic (MDT) moved higher, supported by reports that the co. is considering issuing a jumbo eurobond in Q4 in order to replace its USD debt, taking advantage of near-record low borrowing costs in euro terms. Mosaic Co. (MOS) moved higher after Cowen raised its price target for the co. GrubHub (GRUB) shares popped higher premarket after Citigroup upgraded the restaurant to a buy. Bausch Health Companies Inc (BHC) gained after the health care co. launched its plaque psoriasis lotion. Shopify (SHOP) shares sunk after Wedbush downgraded the co.’s stock to neutral from outperform. FactSet Research Systems (FDS) saw initial upside after the software maker beat earnings expectations, but sunk in later trade. Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) shares rallied ahead of earnings on Thursday, in which the co. is expected to report an increase in quarterly revenue. FedEx (FDX) shares fell after the co. opted to sue the US government, arguing that it should not be held responsible if it accidentally shipped products that violated the recent export ban to some Chinese companies such as Huawei. The move comes ahead of earnings, which it reports after market today (on Tuesday). Tyson Foods (TSN) fell on reports that the US is probing claims that the co. has engaged in poultry price fixing. Wayfair (W) shares plummeted after employees announced a walkout in opposition to furniture sales to migrant detention facilities. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) shares moved after the co. was initiated with an outperform at Credit Suisse. Brighthouse Financials (BHF) shares sunk after the co. was downgraded to neutral at Credit Suisse, who suggested recent drops in interest rates that could reduce distributable earnings.

* FX WRAP: Fed commentary was not as dovish as traders was expecting, which helped keep the USD higher, and the DXY to snap four sessions of losses. An official also suggested President Trump viewed the USD as too strong. Data wise, the Richmond Fed data followed the run of regional Fed surveys soured by escalating US/Mexico tensions in June (tensions which has since subsided), and forward-looking metrics were encouraging. The consumer confidence data saw the headline fall by more than expected, though the inflation gauge was higher. JPY strengthened on news Trump mulled withdrawing from a defence treaty with Japan; elsewhere, the stale BOJ meeting minutes, from its previous meeting, showed a few policymakers calling for the central bank to clarify that policy adjustments would be made without hesitation. Most policymakers were supportive of further easing until inflation is at target. The yen is higher against the buck, as is XAU, which continues its advance above USD 1,400; analysts citing the mix of geopolitical tensions, a weaker USD, as well as the dovish pivot of major central banks. Technicians look for a monthly close above USD 1,400, which would be a bullish sign. Technically, the breaking of USD 1,433 adds to the prospect of a rally towards the USD 1,500 level, and then a key fib level of USD 1,509 (61.8% of the September 2012 to December 2015 decline). The RBNZ rate decision overnight is expected to see a 50 pips NZD price swing, according to break evens; an unchanged decision is expected. MXN was flat against the buck after a retail sales beat. BRL could not build on the pension reform optimism on Tuesday, while COPOM minutes added little to the debate. TRY was up against the buck, with the weekend’s Istanbul election continuing to reverberate, while there is optimism ahead of a meeting between Trump and Erdogan at the G20.

* EUR: The rally from the Sintra low of c.1.1180 to above 1.14 has been rapid, supported by momentum flows after last week’s dovish FOMC. SocGen notes that if momentum continues into the G20 on Friday, the single currency will have reversed three months of losses in just over a week, and will likely post its first monthly rise since December. “That’s impressive. Technically, a melt up to 1.1500-1.1570, this year’s high, cannot be ruled out if Fed chair Powell triggers another round of dollar selling during his speech in NY tonight,” the bank says, “that does not make the move less stretched if we consider a cross section of 5y5y inflation, the basis and EU/US rate differentials. With a steeper EU curve, rising 5y5y inflation and a tighter basis, fair value is currently around one big figure lower nearer 1.13.”

* HAVENS: There is no sign of the long carry trade (short JPY, CHF), on the back of heightened geopolitical tensions. Deutsche Bank says that much will depend on the Fed, with further dovish policy likely to take the shine off of carry. DB warns that we should be mindful of the month-end window, a period during which US corporates become more active in hedging activity. The German bank favours selling USDJPY rallies, saying that 107.80 breaks and suspect rallies to 108.00 should remain limited for this continued grind lower, adding “stick with JPY longs.”

* CNY: China will issue CNY 2bln yuan-denominated bonds in Macau on 4th July, the MoF said. It is to be the first yuan-denominated government bond sale in Macau, which shows central government’s efforts to help diversity Macau’s economy and develop local bond market, and follows similar auctions in Hong Kong, which are used to mop up excess liquidity to support the yuan, analysts have previously said. On the FX front, desks note that the CNY-CNH spread stayed negative yesterday for a second day, which some say is a sign that bearish pressures are contained.

subject: US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLED 6 TICKS HIGHER AT 128-04
analysis_details: Yields were lower by 0-3bps across the curve at settlement. Attention in early trade was on the 10-year yield, which once again breached 2% to the downside around the cash equity open, as well as the negative US 2-year swap spread, which saw a negative reaction in stocks too. The data slate helped support the complex, after weaker consumer confidence, new home sales missing, and another weak regional manufacturing survey headline (though the internals were more encouraging, with new orders rising). Later in the session, Fed’s Bullard leaned back in the notion of a 50bps rate cut in July, preferring 25bps; markets interpreted this as less dovish than hoped for, which saw yields rise and the USD catch a bid, while stocks slipped. Powell’s comments were balanced, but the Fed Chair offered little to suggest a 50bps rate cut was coming, instead Powell choosing to adopt a more circumspect approach. The implied probability of a 50bps rate cut in July has fallen to around 35% from around 42% on Monday. The US 2-year auction was solid, stopping through the screens, while cover was above recent averages. There was little of note in the bidder breakdown. The US sells 5-year notes on Wednesday; SocGen’s analysts say some concession will be needed ahead of the auction on an outright basis, since current 5-year WI yields are trading below all stop-out rates since September 2017. The banks ays that from a relative value perspective, 5s have not got clear set-up ahead of the auction, and current 5s trade rich vs off the runs in asset swap, though it is slightly cheap on the curve vs 2s and 10s. SocGen says it is neutral on the auction.

FX WRAP: USD snaps four sessions of losses after less-dovish-than-expected Fedspeak
analysis_details:
* FX WRAP: Fed commentary was not as dovish as traders was expecting, which helped keep the USD higher, and the DXY to snap four sessions of losses. An official also suggested President Trump viewed the USD as too strong. Data wise, the Richmond Fed data followed the run of regional Fed surveys soured by escalating US/Mexico tensions in June (tensions which has since subsided), and forward-looking metrics were encouraging. The consumer confidence data saw the headline fall by more than expected, though the inflation gauge was higher. JPY strengthened on news Trump mulled withdrawing from a defence treaty with Japan; elsewhere, the stale BOJ meeting minutes, from its previous meeting, showed a few policymakers calling for the central bank to clarify that policy adjustments would be made without hesitation. Most policymakers were supportive of further easing until inflation is at target. The yen is higher against the buck, as is XAU, which continues its advance above USD 1,400; analysts citing the mix of geopolitical tensions, a weaker USD, as well as the dovish pivot of major central banks. Technicians look for a monthly close above USD 1,400, which would be a bullish sign. Technically, the breaking of USD 1,433 adds to the prospect of a rally towards the USD 1,500 level, and then a key fib level of USD 1,509 (61.8% of the September 2012 to December 2015 decline). The RBNZ rate decision overnight is expected to see a 50 pips NZD price swing, according to break evens; an unchanged decision is expected. MXN was flat against the buck after a retail sales beat. BRL could not build on the pension reform optimism on Tuesday, while COPOM minutes added little to the debate. TRY was up against the buck, with the weekend’s Istanbul election continuing to reverberate, while there is optimism ahead of a meeting between Trump and Erdogan at the G20.

* EUR: The rally from the Sintra low of c.1.1180 to above 1.14 has been rapid, supported by momentum flows after last week’s dovish FOMC. SocGen notes that if momentum continues into the G20 on Friday, the single currency will have reversed three months of losses in just over a week, and will likely post its first monthly rise since December. “That’s impressive. Technically, a melt up to 1.1500-1.1570, this year’s high, cannot be ruled out if Fed chair Powell triggers another round of dollar selling during his speech in NY tonight,” the bank says, “that does not make the move less stretched if we consider a cross section of 5y5y inflation, the basis and EU/US rate differentials. With a steeper EU curve, rising 5y5y inflation and a tighter basis, fair value is currently around one big figure lower nearer 1.13.”

* HAVENS: There is no sign of the long carry trade (short JPY, CHF), on the back of heightened geopolitical tensions. Deutsche Bank says that much will depend on the Fed, with further dovish policy likely to take the shine off of carry. DB warns that we should be mindful of the month-end window, a period during which US corporates become more active in hedging activity. The German bank favours selling USDJPY rallies, saying that 107.80 breaks and suspect rallies to 108.00 should remain limited for this continued grind lower, adding “stick with JPY longs.”

* CNY: China will issue CNY 2bln yuan-denominated bonds in Macau on 4th July, the MoF said. It is to be the first yuan-denominated government bond sale in Macau, which shows central government’s efforts to help diversity Macau’s economy and develop local bond market, and follows similar auctions in Hong Kong, which are used to mop up excess liquidity to support the yuan, analysts have previously said. On the FX front, desks note that the CNY-CNH spread stayed negative yesterday for a second day, which some say is a sign that bearish pressures are contained.

analysis_details: The energy complex traded in a somewhat of a limbo on Tuesday, with the usual suspects of geopolitics and trade concerns providing support and resistance respectively. Iran announcing the “closing of diplomacy forever” and President Trump threatening “obliteration” if the US was attacked was providing justified concerns over supply out of the region. Investors are also tepid ahead of this weekend’s G20 summit, with analysts sceptical on a material breakthrough, with all else remaining could lead to a further deterioration in global growth provided tariffs remain present. It is worth reminding that OPEC+ will be paying close attention to the G20 outcome in how it decides to move forward with production cut extensions, which are widely expected to be rolled over but could be subject to changes in the magnitude of the cuts. The market is also looking ahead to the API’s US energy inventory report after the bell, where crude stocks are seen drawing 2.5mln bbls, distillates building 0.5mln bbls, and gasoline stocks building 0.3mln bbls; Genscape sees Cushing, Oklahoma drawing 165k bbls.

subject: Fed Chair Powell says many on the Fed see a case for more accomodation but don't want to overreact to single data points; rates are low and are likely to remain so
content:
On Policy/Rates:

  • Says in a general matter it is better to act preemptively and not let any economic downturns gain steam
  • Sees the market’s tepid inflation expectations as a reason for lowering rates
  • Says it is important for the FOMC not to overreact
  • Says over the last few years the neutral rate has drifted lower; unlikely to see interest rates at 5% given the global environment
  • Says there might be a reason to deploy a counter-cyclical capital buffer in the future
  • Says there is still room to use QE if necessary, it had previously helped to stimulate the economy

On Inflation/Outlook:

  • Says unemployment is low and inflation is running near target; solid fundamentals are supporting continued growth and strong job creation
  • Sees tariffs as a one-time price increase, not a driver of inflation going forward
  • Says FOMC baseline outlooks remain favourable against backdrop of heightened uncertainties
  • Says business and agricultural contacts reported heightened concerns over trade developments; says trade concerns may have contributed to the drop in business confidence and investment
  • Says he sees the slowing trend in manufacturing globally
  • Fed is monitoring many economic metrics, not just one sole measure

On Politics:

  • Says the Fed is independent and is insulated from short term political pressures
  • Says it is widely understood the US Federal budget is not sustainable
analysis_details: Newswires attribute further risk downside to Powell’s comments, perhaps because he has not provided any explicit signal of a 50bps rate cut in July. Powell also seemed sanguine on the economy, noting fundamentals are supporting continued growth. His comments on inflation were also benign, noting again that it is running "somewhat" below the Fed's target, but adding FOMC has expected it to pick up. He also said that baseline outlooks remain favourable in the face of heightened uncertainties – again, lending to the view that Powell is not immediately concerned enough to loosen policy too much. Powell also has reiterated that the Fed is monitoring many economic metrics, not just one sole measure, and he is taking time to emphasise the importance of the FOMC not overreacting

PREVIEW: US to sell USD 40bln 2-year notes at 1800 BST/1300 EDT
content:
* WEEK’S SUPPLY: This week, the US Treasury will auction USD 131bln of 2-year (USD 40bln, Tuesday), 5-year (USD 41boln, Wednesday), 7-year (USD 32bln, Thursday), as well as a 2-year FRN (USD 18bln, Wednesday). USD 72bln matures at the monthend settlement, implying USD 59bln of net cash will be raised, TD Securities says.  

* 2-YEAR PREVIEW: From a relative value perspective, the current 2-year note is lacking set up ahead of Tuesday’s auction, and trades rich on asset swap versus older 2s. “The auction is expected to benefit from dovish June FOMC meeting,” SocGen says, “similarly, our view for a modest steepening of the 2s10s curve led by the front-end should also support demand for the auction.” However, SocGen warns that dealer holdings in the 2-3-year sector has risen to a record high, which might limit demand from dealers, and will need support from investment funds and foreign participants in order to perform well. Last month’s auction was well received against the backdrop of global trade wars, and the demand from the foreign and investment bid was solid. SocGen is positive on the 2s auction.

subject: Fed’s Bullard (voter, dovish dissenter) does not prefer 50bps July FOMC rate cut; Says he voted for rate cut since inflation is running below target, and inflation expectations are deteriorating
content:
• The inverted yield curve contributed to his decision for an insurance rate cut
  • Bullard says inflation expectations debate will not be resolved in Osaka G20 summit, explaining why he voted to cut in June vs waiting for July
  • By not cutting, Fed has put higher probability on the July meeting, and Bullard does not like that tactic; says if the conditions are right today, you should move today
  • On a 50bps rate cut, Bullard says 50bps would be ‘overdone’, but he doesn’t want to prejudge the meeting
  • Bullard says risks of a recession is higher than in the past, though is hopeful that if the FOMC acts, it will straighten the yield curve out, reducing the chances of a recession
reaction_details: Stocks began selling off after Bullard intimated a 50bps rate cut would be going too far, with the market seemingly pricing in less dovishness from one of the most dovish FOMC participants
analysis_details: Dovish dissenter Bullard is leaning back on the 50bps cut argument, and this follows the cautious comments from non-voter Kaplan yesterday. It might suggest that there is an argument that the market has gone too far in pricing Fed rate cuts.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: tight Tuesday ranges awaiting real run in to month end and G20
content:
DXY

The index remains tethered to the 96.000 pivot awaiting a more decisive break and/or major move elsewhere to either extend post-FOMC losses or mount a meaningful rebound. For now, dips below the round number have held above 96.820-740 support even though the 200 WMA (95.964) has technically been breached, while bounces have not penetrated or really threated chart resistance ahead of 96.500 or early month/pre-Fed peaks. However, Wednesday could be the next watershed for the Dollar with supposedly strong selling for portfolio rebalancing likely to start in earnest 2 days ahead of the final trading day of June, Q2 and H1. More immediately, any reaffirmation of dovish guidance from Powell, Bostic and/or Barkin may impact as trade and geopolitical factors continue to weigh on sentiment.

G10

Not much, if any deviation in Usd/major pairings as the clock ticks down to the G20 and risk-off positioning remains prevalent, albeit selective and not exactly rife. Indeed, while the Yen climbs back above 107.00 it is still lagging a bit behind the high beta and more sensitive to mood swings Kiwi that heads in to the RNBZ close to 0.6650 and ‘comfortably’ over 1.0500 against its Aussie counterpart. To recap, the Nzd derived some support from better than forecast NZ trade data overnight, while benchmark rates are widely seen on hold – see our headline feed or research suite for a more detailed preview. Elsewhere, Aud/Usd remains confined between 0.6955-75, but the Loonie got a brief boost from much stronger than expected Canadian wholesale trade to test recent highs and reported bids around 1.3150 before returning to the middle of a 1.3152-96 band. The Franc was subject to suspicions of SNB action and safe-haven unwinding, as Usd/Chf bounced from just under 0.9700 and Eur/Chf pared some losses below 1.1100, but the cross remained toppy as the single currency failed to reclaim 1.1400 vs the Greenback. However, Sterling looks all set to end the EU session as the major loser/laggard with Cable fading ahead of 1.2800 and revisiting support not far off the big figure below, such as a Fib and short term chart levels, while Eur/Gbp bounced towards the upper end of a 0.8953-17 range after the failure to sustain early technical and stop-driven gains vs the Buck.

EM 

The Lira stands out as a relative outperformer for a change, and spill-over Istanbul election relief appears to be a factor alongside an impending one-to-one meeting between Turkish President Erdogan and his US counterpart that might diffuse some of the S-400 vs F-35 heat. Usd/Try is hovering nearer the base of 5.8300-7590 parameters vs Usd/Mxn and Usd/Brl both circa 0.2% higher despite above consensus Mexican retail sales and latest positive sounding reports about the progress of Brazil’s Pension Reform Bill.

content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) is to expand operations in Seattle, adding 2k employees in the city over the next 5 years.
  • Exxon Mobil (XOM) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels), Linde (LIN) (Materials/Chemicals) – The two co.s signed a long term agreement, where Linde will invest USD 1.4bln to expand its Singapore gasification complex, combining it with Exxon’s hydrogen and synthesis operations in the region, with expected launch in 2023.
  • Intel Corp. (INTC) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) is planning to cut prices for its eighth & ninth generation desktop processors by between 10% and 15%, reported DigiTimes.
  • Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) – Jeffries has maintained its underperform rating on the technology giant; analyst DiFucci said that Microsoft shares are "materially overvalued", citing evidence that undermines the assumption that Microsoft Azure profitability will come with scale (much like as it did with Amazon’s Web Services).
  • The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) is in talks to make a USD 200mln investment in a media subsidiary of the Indonesian co. Media Nusantara Citra for ten years.
  • Walmart’s (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centres) Mexico division is now offering grocery delivery via Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) owned messaging service WhatsApp.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc (GOOG) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) subsidiary Sidewalk Labs, which has proposed a "smart city" project in a Toronto that it says would create thousands of jobs whilst also cutting greenhouse-gas emissions, is facing resistance from the project's government sponsor. Sidewalk Labs’ plans reportedly go beyond the project initially proposed by the government, reported the WSJ. Elsewhere, a number of rivals to the Alphabet, including TripAdvisor (TRIP) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) and Yelp (YELP) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services), are reportedly preparing to help US officials with an anti-trust probe of the technology giant. They allege that Alphabet has favoured its own content over their own.
  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) announced that its annual Prime Day will last for 48 hours for the first time this year, running from 15-16 July.
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) - A senior member of the SNB is reportedly “open-minded” about Facebook’s new cryptocurrency. However, the UK’s Financial Conduct Authority said there was "insufficient" detail to understand Facebook's plans to expand into payments with its cryptocurrency launch.
  • Kraft Heinz (KHC) (Consumer Staples/Food Products) – Warren Buffet has denied previous reports that tensions had brewed between himself and co-stake holder 3G Capital but reiterated that he overpaid for the co. back in 2015, he said on CNBC.

S&P 500

  • AbbVie (ABBV) (Health Care/Biotechnology), Allergan (AGN) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) - AbbVie is to buy Allergan for in excess of USD 60bln in a cash and stock deal, at USD 120.30 per share and 0.8660 ABBV shares for each AGN. The deal has an equity value of USD 63bln and is expected to close in early 2020; AbbVie is beholden to a termination fee of USD 1.25bln under certain conditions. The Deal is expected to be 10% accretive to adj. EPS  over the first full year following the deal closing and expected to provide annual pre-tax synergies and other cost reductions in excess of USD 2bln in year three. Allergan looks set to open well in the green and drag some peers with it, such as Mylan (MYL) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) which is also performing well pre-market.
  • FedEx Corporation (FDX) (Industrials/Air Freight & Logistics) is to sue the US government, arguing it should not be held responsible if it accidentally shipped products that violated the recent export ban to some Chinese companies such as Huawei.
  • Kellogg Co. (K) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) has had its estimates lowered at Argus, although they did maintain their Buy rating for the food maker. Analyst Graja said in a note that shares are attractively valued but he remains concerned about the company's “challenging operating environment”, but expects it to benefit from cost-savings initiatives, as well as recent acquisitions. Elsewhere, the co. was also downgraded to underweight from equal weight at Consumer Edge.
  • Lennar Corp. (LEN) (Consumer Discretionary/Homebuilding) (USD) reports Q2 EPS 1.30 (exp. 1.14), revenue 5.56bln (exp. 5.1bln), new orders of 14,518 homes, backlog of 19,061 homes. The co. said, “our second quarter results benefited from both first quarter deliveries postponed by weather as well as a recovering housing market”. D. R. Horton (DHI) (Consumer Discretionary/Homebuilding) and PulteGroup Inc. (PHM) (Consumer Discretionary/Homebuilding) look set to open in the green alongside Lennar after these positive earnings.
  • Lockheed Martin Corp.’s (LMT) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) F35 has been used by the UK Airforce in operations for the first time, reported the Telegraph.   • Northern Trust Corp. (NTRS) (Financials/Asset Management & Custody Banks) and Confluence announced a partnership to deliver financial and regulatory reporting solutions to Northern Trust’s European asset management clients.
  • Medtronic plc (MDT) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) is considering issuing a jumbo eurobond in Q4 in order to replace its USD debt, taking advantage of near-record low borrowing costs in euro terms.

  • Canopy Growth Corp (CGC) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) CEO Linton said that although the company will continue with M&A deals, it is done acquiring other producers.
  • FactSet (FDS) (Financials/Capital Markets) reports Q3 adj. EPS 2.62 (exp. 2.36), revenue 0.365bln (exp. 0.359bln), raises FY19 adj. EPS view to 9.80-9.90 from 9.50-9.65 (exp. 9.59), narrows FY19 revenue view to 1.42bln-1.44bln from 1.41bln-1.45bln (exp. 1.43bln).

subject: Iran's Secretary of Supreme National Security Council states that Iran are to begin the 2nd phase of reducing commitments under the Nuclear deal as of July 7th
US Ambassador says we will continue to put maximum pressure on Iran until it changes its behaviour, and we will look into what more we can do in terms of sanctions
analysis_details: This does follow US President Trump signing an executive order putting strong sanctions on Iran including the Supreme Leader in response to the recent drone attack, while he stated that the US does not want conflict with Iran and would love to reach a deal with Iran. Additionally, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin commented that Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif will be hit with sanctions later this week and that 8 senior commanders of Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corp will also be hit with sanctions

subject: China’s Premier Li states that they will reduce negative list on market access, in the context of a meeting on improving the business environment., state media
analysis_details: For reference, this refers to a market access negative list system in China which as of 25th December 2018 is applicable to foreign and domestic companies.

subject: Iran's Foreign Minister Zarif says Iran will never pursue nuclear weapons
RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 25th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European Indices [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.3%] are somewhat subdued following the lacklusture Asia-Pac handover
  • Iran Foreign Ministry spokesman Mousavi states that the US sanctions mean the permanent closure of the diplomatic channel
  • AbbVie (ABBV) is looking to buy Allergan (AGN) for in excess of USD 60bln in a cash and stock deal
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Richmond Fed, ECB’s Coeure, Fed’s Williams, Bostic, Powell, Barkin, Bullard, supply from the US, earnings from FedEx and Micron

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets followed suit to the lacklustre performance among global peers as geopolitical concerns remained in the limelight after the US announced fresh sanctions on Iran. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) were subdued although losses in Australia were stemmed by strength in the miners amid continued gains across the metals complex, while Tokyo sentiment was clouded by a stronger currency. Hang Seng (-1.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) underperformed overnight after the PBoC continued to refrain from liquidity operations and due to ongoing trade uncertainty heading into the G20, while banks were among the worst hit in a continued fallout from the Baoshang Bank failure and Citic Securities also suggested domestic liquidity conditions could be volatile next month if PBoC citing increased corporate cash demand for tax payments. Finally, 10yr JGBs were slightly higher as they benefitted from the cautious sentiment and following similar gains in T-notes but with upside limited after a mixed 20yr JGB auction in which the b/c substantially retreated from the prior month’s record high.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8580 (Prev. 6.8503)

US senior administration official says President Trump will likely meet Chinese President Xi on Saturday at the G20 but still needs to be confirmed, while the suggested it is an opportunity to see where China is on the trade dispute and that President Trump is happy with any outcome. (Newswires)

China Mofcom stated that Vice Premier Liu He conducted a phone call with USTR Lighthizer in which they exchanged views, while it added that China and US trade teams have agreed to keep communication. (Newswires)

India is reportedly mulling offering incentives to attract companies shifting from China amid the trade war with the US, according to sources cited by SCMP; ‘Financial incentives such as preferential tax rates and the tax holiday provided by Vietnam to lure companies are among measures being considered, the person said’. (SCMP)

BoJ Minutes from April 24th-25th meeting stated it will take time to reach 2% target and that it is appropriate to persistently continue with easing. Minutes also reiterated that financial conditions in Japan remain highly accommodative and that Japan’s economy had been on a moderate expanding trend although exports have shown weakness recently. Most members shared view that medium to long-term inflation expectations were likely to gradually converge to 2%, although one member said the BoJ should flexibly and decisively conduct additional easing if inflation momentum was lost, while another member said it was necessary to strengthen monetary easing at this point to achieve the price target as soon as possible.  (Newswires)

US

US President Trump said Fed Chair Powell is "incorrect" that he is entitled to serving a four-year term that expires in 2022 and stated that he thinks he has the power to remove Powell if he wanted to but has no plans to do anything. (The Hill)

US National Security Advisor Bolton says all Iran has to do is negotiate with the US over the nuclear program. (Newswires)

US Disarmament Ambassador states that if Iran continues to attack the US, then there will be a decisive response; US will not initiate a conflict against Iran and US President Trump is keeping a diplomatic path open. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Iran Foreign Ministry spokesman Mousavi said the latest US sanctions means closing channel of diplomacy forever. Subsequently, Iranian President Rouhani says US sanctions on Iran will fail, reported via state TV. And the Economy Minster states that Iranis prepared to tackle the US sanctions. (Newswires/Tasnim)

US senior administration official said President Trump will meet Russia President Putin at the G20 and will discuss topics including Iran, Ukraine, Middle East, Syria and arms control issues, while the official added that Trump will not meet North Korea's Kim during his visit to Seoul. (Newswires)

North Korean newspaper stated the US should not misjudge the current situation and warned that Washington will face defeat and humiliation if it sticks to its old way of thinking, according to South Korea press reports. Elsewhere, US Defense Intelligence Agency chief said the intelligence community assesses that North Korea’s leader is not ready to denuclearize. (Yonhap/Newswires)

Turkish Court has ruled to release US consulate worker who is on trial from house arrest, but they will not be allowed to leave the country. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM candidate Boris Johnson said he will ensure a plan to deliver Brexit by end of October and pledged to leave EU on Oct. 31st. Johnson stated that the UK needs to prepare for Brexit under WTO rules even though he does not believe we will end up there, while he also thinks he can get a no-deal Brexit through parliament and that there should be creative ambiguity over how and when the EU divorce bill gets paid. (BBC) Separate reports suggest that Former Conservative Chancellor Clarke would be willing to bring down a Boris Johnson-led government in order to avert a no deal Brexit. (Telegraph) Ireland is facing demand by other EU countries to set out detailed plans how it will manage a no-deal Brexit amid increasing fears it may be unavoidable. (Telegraph)

EU leaders assume that UK MP’s would trigger a general election rather than allow the UK to leave the EU in a no-deal scenario; with EU figures being cynical towards UK PM candidate Johnson’s approach to the Brexit negotiation with the EU., ITV’s Peston. (Twitter)

ECB's de Guindos banks’ profitability prospects could be dampened by deteriorating growth expectations, adding to structural weaknesses, adds that the overall effect of our monetary policy on bank profitability has so far been broadly neutral. (Newswires)

Italian Economy Minister Tria says he does not foresee any obstacles with the EU in striking an agreement, for a zero growth economy such as Italy, a 2.1% deficit/GDP ratio represents a more than prudent fiscal policy. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

A relatively subdued start for European stocks [Eurostoxx 50 -0.3%] following on from a lacklustre performance in Asia amid geopolitical tensions, month/quarter/HY rebalancing and caution ahead of the G20 summit. Major bourses are mostly lower with no clear standouts. Sectors are largely mixed albeit some strength is seen in material names as copper rebounds and gold extends on 6yr highs. Thus, Anglo American (+0.6%), Rio Tinto (+1.0%), Fresnillo (+0.6%) shares are all supported. Looking at individual movers, Capgemini (+7.0%) shares spiked higher at the open after the Co. agreed to purchase Altran Technologies (+21.3%) in an attempt to tap into the engineering outsourcing services market. Meanwhile. KPN (-2.2%) shares declined following the announcement of its CEO’s departure. Finally, broker-driven movers include CRH Hansen (-2.1%), Telenor (-1.3%), and Iliad (-5.1%).

AbbVie (ABBV) is looking to buy Allergan (AGN) for in excess of USD 60bln in a cash and stock deal, at USD 188 per share, according to WSJ. (WSJ)

FX

NZD/JPY/GBP - The standout majors and outperformers, albeit with the aid of ongoing Usd weakness as the DXY struggles to keep tabs on the 96.000 level. The Kiwi has received a timely boost just ahead of Wednesday’s RBNZ policy meet in the form of NZ trade revealing moderately better than expected m/m and y/y balances, with Nzd/Usd extending gains above 0.6600 to just over 0.6650 at one stage, while the AUD/Nzd cross has retreated through 1.0500 as the Aussie continues to meet resistance/offers recent highs and the psychological 0.7000 mark. Meanwhile, the Yen rallied through 107.00 on heightened risk-aversion sparked by US sanctions against Iran and Tehran’s response that the move means no return to lines of diplomatic communication before losing some steam and retreating back below the big figure towards decent option expiries at 107.25 (1 bn). Elsewhere, the Pound finally breached a key Fib at 1.2768 and Cable advanced to 1.2780+ after stops around 1.2770 were tripped, while Eur/Gbp pulled back from just above 0.8950 to sub-0.8920 as the single currency stalled across the board rather than anything more fundamentally supportive for Sterling.

EUR/CHF - As noted above, the Euro has faded after making more headway against the Dollar and forging above 1.1400, with several weekly chart levels spanning 1.1416-85 capping the rally on top of a Fib at 1.1460. However, the Franc has reversed even further from best levels circa 1.1060 and 0.9695 vs the Buck amidst vague market talk or speculation about official intervention to curb demand for one of the other traditional safe-havens. On that note, GOLD has seen more upside having breached Usd1400/oz and spiked to fresh multi-year highs only a few cents shy of Usd1440.

NOK/SEK - Marked divergence between the Scandi Crowns as Eur/Nok remains in bear retracement mode after last week’s hawkish Norges Bank hike and underpinned within 9.6910-6645 parameters, but Eur/Sek continues to retreat on a more technical and pre-emptive basis through 10.5500, as the Riksbank maintains its tightening bias in wake of firmer Swedish inflation data and not really fazed by a slowdown in PPI that is largely oil-related. Back to the charts, 200 DMA support may cushion the Nok from further losses as the line comes in at 9.949.

New Zealand Trade Balance (NZD)(May) M/M 264M vs. Exp. 250M (Prev. 422M, Rev. 383M). (Newswires) New Zealand Exports (NZD)(May) 5.81B vs. Exp. 5.61B (Prev. 5.55B, Rev. 5.50B) New Zealand Imports (NZD)(May) 5.54B vs. Exp. 5.40B (Prev. 5.11B, Rev. 5.12B)

Notable FX Expiries:

- USD/JPY: 107.25 (1BLN), 108.00-10 (1BLN)

- AUD/JPY: 74.50 (655M), 75.50-55 (500M)

FIXED INCOME

Marginal new intraday lows for Gilts at 130.50 (-13 ticks vs +18 ticks earlier) as investors shied away from long-dated DMO issuance at depressed and seemingly less attractive yields given the sparse subscription and lengthy tail at the 2049 sale. Indeed, the UK offering was arguably weaker than Germany’s Schatz that saw a relatively large retention and was technically uncovered, although that is not uncommon of course. Hence, 2 year futures are holding around parity, albeit just, while Bunds have not quite revisited their previous Eurex session base. Elsewhere, US Treasuries have been dragged down from overnight peaks alongside EU counterparts and the curve is now essentially steady vs considerably flatter at one stage amidst spurious talk that the US and China may call a trade truce, though this could be alluding to the recent WTO suspension of appeals until December 31. Note also, some consolidation likely ahead of a packed pm agenda, including data, a raft of Fed speakers and prominently chair Powell plus the 1st of this week’s supply remit.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are choppy with the both benchmarks relatively flat below USD 58/bbl and USD 65/bbl as eyes are kept on the rising tensions between US and Iran and G20 developments ahead of next week’s OPEC+ meeting. Participants expect the cartel and allies to roll over the output cut pact into the second half of the year after nearly all members (ex-Russia) stated that it is in the best interest of the market. Immediate headline risks aside, tonight will see the release of the weekly API crude stocks as the street looks for a headline inventory decline of 2.9mln barrels, albeit price action may be short-lived given the aforementioned reasons. Elsewhere, gold prices remain buoyed after hitting levels last seen in August 2013 (intraday high USD 1439/oz). The yellow metal has been supported by the safe haven demand amid geopolitical tensions, and a weaker Dollar post-FOMC. Thus, Gold traders today will be eyeing any further Iran/US escalation and Fed Chair Powell’s speech scheduled for 1800BST/1300EDT which will touch on monetary policy and the economic outlook. Powell aside, other 2019 Fed voters on the docket include Fed’s Williams, and Bullard (dissenter). Turning to base metals, copper prices rebounded and reclaimed USD 2.7/lb to the upside as the red metal as extended strikes at Coldeco’s Chuquicamata copper mine roused supply concerns. Finally, China Rebar prices surged to the nearly 8yr highs as steel mill continue to curb production amid pollution warnings.

subject: Italian Deputy PM Salvini says he is not ready to give any budget deficit commitments for 2020
AbbVie (ABBV) is to buy Allergan (AGN) for in excess of USD 60bln in a cash and stock deal, at USD 120.30 per share and 0.8660 ABBV shares for each AGN, according to WSJ
content:
• The deal has an equity value of USD 63bln and is expected to close in early 2020
  • Deal is expected to be 10% accretive to adj. EPS  over the first full year following the deal closing; expected to provide annual pre-tax synergies and other cost reductions in excess of USD 2bln in year three
reaction_details:
• In a pre-market reaction, AGN rose approximately 35%, ABBV fell by 6%
  • Other relevant healthcare names included Teva (TEVA) rising by 4%, and Mylan (MYL) falling 2%

Meanwhile, the Yen rallied through 107.00 on heightened risk-aversion sparked by US sanctions against Iran and Tehran’s response that the move means no return to lines of diplomatic communication before losing some steam and retreating back below the big figure towards decent option expiries at 107.25 (1 bn). Elsewhere, the Pound finally breached a key Fib at 1.2768 and Cable advanced to 1.2780+ after stops around 1.2770 were tripped, while Eur/Gbp pulled back from just above 0.8950 to sub-0.8920 as the single currency stalled across the board rather than anything more fundamentally supportive for Sterling.

EUR/CHF

As noted above, the Euro has faded after making more headway against the Dollar and forging above 1.1400, with several weekly chart levels spanning 1.1416-85 capping the rally on top of a Fib at 1.1460. However, the Franc has reversed even further from best levels circa 1.1060 and 0.9695 vs the Buck amidst vague market talk or speculation about official intervention to curb demand for one of the other traditional safe-havens. On that note, GOLD has seen more upside having breached Usd1400/oz and spiked to fresh multi-year highs only a few cents shy of Usd1440.

NOK/SEK

Marked divergence between the Scandi Crowns as Eur/Nok remains in bear retracement mode after last week’s hawkish Norges Bank hike and underpinned within 9.6910-6645 parameters, but Eur/Sek continues to retreat on a more technical and pre-emptive basis through 10.5500, as the Riksbank maintains its tightening bias in wake of firmer Swedish inflation data and not really fazed by a slowdown in PPI that is largely oil-related. Back to the charts, 200 DMA support may cushion the Nok from further losses as the line comes in at 9.949.

subject: UK debt and STIR futures gradually conform to firmer external leads
content: In contrast to Monday’s bullish return to Liffe, Gilts and Short Sterling contracts have been somewhat reticent to advance further with the 10 year debt future marked down to 130.55 initially and dipping a bit lower to 130.52 before finding its feet and tracking the more pronounced bid in Bunds. The ensuing rebound has petered out at 130.81, +18 ticks, while the fresh Eurex peak is 172.86, +39 ticks and only 2 ticks shy of the June 18 contract high. Note, the equivalent for Gilts is 130.92 set on the same day, but UK bonds may continue to lag in the run up to long end DMO issuance (Gbp2.25 bn 2049 tap). content: The core Eurozone bond embarked on another foray to the upside after a flattish open, but lost momentum or failed to muster enough impetus for a serious attempt to breach recent peaks protecting last Tuesday’s Sep19 contract high. On the flip-side, retracements are relatively shallow amidst heightened global trade and geopolitical concerns, with tensions between Iran and the US ramped up further in wake of the latest sanctions that have prompted Tehran to declare an end to dialogue. Looking at Eurex price action so far, Bunds are holding a few ticks above par within a 172.45-66 range vs yesterday’s 172.47 close just ahead of the EU cash equity opens, more ECB speakers and a hefty slate of supply including Italian multi-tranche end of month auctions and a Eur5 bn German Schatz tap alongside long-dated UK Gilts.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

25th June 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets followed suit to the lacklustre performance among global peers as geopolitical concerns remained in the limelight after the US announced fresh sanctions on Iran. ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) were subdued although losses in Australia were stemmed by strength in the miners amid continued gains across the metals complex, while Tokyo sentiment was clouded by a stronger currency. Hang Seng (-1.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.8%) underperformed overnight after the PBoC continued to refrain from liquidity operations and due to ongoing trade uncertainty heading into the G20, while banks were among the worst hit in a continued fallout from the Baoshang Bank failure and Citic Securities also suggested domestic liquidity conditions could be volatile next month if PBoC citing increased corporate cash demand for tax payments.

FTSE 100

Mining names - Gold prices extended on 6-year highs as it benefitted from the weaker USD and due to its safe-haven status. subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 25th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian indices are subdued following on from the US’ imposition of sanctions on Iran
  • DXY continued its recent downtrend and slipped below 96.00, leading USD/JPY beneath 107.00
  • US placed strong sanctions on Iran, including the Supreme Leader; Iran’s Foreign Ministry Spokesman states that the sanctions mean the diplomatic channel is closed forever
  • US Official states that the Trump-Xi meeting is likely the 2nd day of G20, but this is yet to be confirmed
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Richmond Fed, RBA’s Bullock, ECB’s de Guindos, Coeure, Fed’s Williams, Bostic, Powell, Barkin, Bullard, supply from UK, US and Germany, earnings from Fedex and Micron

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets followed suit to the lacklustre performance among global peers as geopolitical concerns remained in the limelight after the US announced fresh sanctions on Iran. ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) were subdued although losses in Australia were stemmed by strength in the miners amid continued gains across the metals complex, while Tokyo sentiment was clouded by a stronger currency. Hang Seng (-1.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.8%) underperformed overnight after the PBoC continued to refrain from liquidity operations and due to ongoing trade uncertainty heading into the G20, while banks were among the worst hit in a continued fallout from the Baoshang Bank failure and Citic Securities also suggested domestic liquidity conditions could be volatile next month if PBoC citing increased corporate cash demand for tax payments. Finally, 10yr JGBs were slightly higher as they benefitted from the cautious sentiment and following similar gains in T-notes but with upside limited after a mixed 20yr JGB auction in which the b/c substantially retreated from the prior month’s record high.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8580 (Prev. 6.8503)

US senior administration official says President Trump will likely meet Chinese President Xi on Saturday at the G20 but still needs to be confirmed, while the suggested it is an opportunity to see where China is on the trade dispute and that President Trump is happy with any outcome. (Newswires)

China Mofcom stated that Vice Premier Liu He conducted a phone call with USTR Lighthizer in which they exchanged views, while it added that China and US trade teams have agreed to keep communication. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor highlighted challenges of US-China relations ahead of the G20 in which he suggested that the current atmosphere between China and the US is not good and he has learned China's stance now is that it is holding constructive and positive attitude towards upcoming China-US summit but is also fully preparing for its failure and an escalating trade war. (Twitter)

BoJ Minutes from April 24th-25th meeting stated it will take time to reach 2% target and that it is appropriate to persistently continue with easing. Minutes also reiterated that financial conditions in Japan remain highly accommodative and that Japan’s economy had been on a moderate expanding trend although exports have shown weakness recently. Most members shared view that medium to long-term inflation expectations were likely to gradually converge to 2%, although one member said the BoJ should flexibly and decisively conduct additional easing if inflation momentum was lost, while another member said it was necessary to strengthen monetary easing at this point to achieve the price target as soon as possible.  (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM candidate Boris Johnson said he will ensure a plan to deliver Brexit by end of October and pledged to leave EU on Oct. 31st. Johnson stated that the UK needs to prepare for Brexit under WTO rules even though he does not believe we will end up there, while he also thinks he can get a no-deal Brexit through parliament and that there should be creative ambiguity over how and when the EU divorce bill gets paid. (BBC) Separate reports suggest that Former Conservative Chancellor Clarke would be willing to bring down a Boris Johnson-led government in order to avert a no deal Brexit. (Telegraph) Ireland is facing demand by other EU countries to set out detailed plans how it will manage a no-deal Brexit amid increasing fears it may be unavoidable. (Telegraph)

FX

DXY continued its recent downtrend and slipped below 96.00 amid mounting Fed rate cut bets which benefitted its major counterparts with EUR/USD now at the 1.1400 handle, while GBP/USD returned to near 1.2750 although further upside was restricted by nearby resistance levels and amid ongoing Brexit-related uncertainty. Elsewhere, the predominantly risk-averse tone spurred flows into safe-haven JPY which pressured USD/JPY to sub-107.00, while antipodeans also took advantage of the USD-woes in early trade with NZD/USD the outperformer after better than expected trade data, although this eventually dragged AUD/NZD below 1.0500 and forced AUD/USD to give back its gains.

 

New Zealand Trade Balance (NZD)(May) M/M 264M vs. Exp. 250M (Prev. 422M, Rev. 383M). (Newswires) New Zealand Exports (NZD)(May) 5.81B vs. Exp. 5.61B (Prev. 5.55B, Rev. 5.50B) New Zealand Imports (NZD)(May) 5.54B vs. Exp. 5.40B (Prev. 5.11B, Rev. 5.12B) 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures down nearly 1% amid the risk averse tone and amid a pullback from resistance at USD 58.00/bbl, while the latest OPEC+ commentary also did crude no favours as Russian Energy Minister Novak recently suggested it is still too early to say if the OPEC deal will be into H2. Gold prices extended on 6-year highs as it benefitted from the weaker USD and due to its safe-haven status. Copper was also kept afloat despite the downbeat sentiment as support held at USD 2.700/lb and amid gains in Chinese commodity prices in which Shanghai Rebar printed its highest since 2011.

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump signed an executive order putting strong sanctions on Iran including the Supreme Leader in response to the recent drone attack, while he stated that the US does not want conflict with Iran and would love to reach a deal with Iran. In related news, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said increased sanctions on Iran were in the works prior to the recent attack and that the new sanctions will lock up billions more in Iranian assets. Mnuchin also commented that Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif will be hit with sanctions later this week and that 8 senior commanders of Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corp will also be hit with sanctions. (Newswires/Twitter)

Iran Foreign Ministry spokesman Mousavi said the latest US sanctions means closing channel of diplomacy forever. There were also reports that Iran will not accept dialogue with the US while it is under the threat of sanctions, while its ambassador to the UN said the atmosphere for dialogue with the US is not ready yet and that the new US sanctions show that the US has no respect for international law and order. (Newswires/Twitter)

US senior administration official said President Trump will meet Russia President Putin at the G20 and will discuss topics including Iran, Ukraine, Middle East, Syria and arms control issues, while the official added that Trump will not meet North Korea's Kim during his visit to Seoul. (Newswires)

North Korean newspaper stated the US should not misjudge the current situation and warned that Washington will face defeat and humiliation if it sticks to its old way of thinking, according to South Korea press reports. Elsewhere, US Defense Intelligence Agency chief said the intelligence community assesses that North Korea’s leader is not ready to denuclearize. (Yonhap/Newswires)

 

US

 

The T-Plex traded range bound earlier on before gaining traction going into the US session, seeing it comfortably in the green for settlement. Participants are likely to be cautious on the loading up of risk ahead of the G-20 summit and the geopolitical noise in the background. Analysts note the rally was assisted by thin volume, in addition to a chunky 28k+ TYU9 block purchase by a hedge fund as the European session came to a close, which was accompanied by a 4k+ block sale of ultra longs seeing the curve steepen. At settlement, the belly of the curve saw the most action (5-year yield down by c. 5.5bps); spreads were mixed, with the 2s/5s flattening by over 1bps, whilst the 5s/10s steepened by c. 0.5bps. US T-note futures (U9) settled 13+ ticks higher at 127-30.

US President Trump said Fed Chair Powell is "incorrect" that he is entitled to serving a four-year term that expires in 2022 and stated that he thinks he has the power to remove Powell if he wanted to but has no plans to do anything. (The Hill)

Fed’s Kaplan (non-voter, dove) said it is wise to take time to consider if there is a need to change rates and that he is concerned adding monetary stimulus will contribute to the build-up of excesses and imbalances. Kaplan also commented that current interest rates are in the neighbourhood of neutral and that it is too early to judge whether trade and global growth uncertainties will hurt the US, while he added that downside risks to the US economy have increased. (Newswires)

ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) are mixed with Australia kept afloat by strength in the miners amid continued gains across the metals complex, while sentiment in Tokyo is subdued by a stronger currency. Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.2%) underperform overnight after the PBoC continued to refrain from liquidity operations and due to ongoing trade uncertainty heading into the G20, while a US senior administration official stated that the Trump-Xi meeting will likely occur on the 2nd day of G20 but added that it still needs to be confirmed and President Trump is happy with any outcome.

In FX markets, the DXY continues its recent downtrend and has slipped below the 96.00 level amid mounting Fed rate cut bets which has benefitted its major counterparts with EUR/USD now trading at the 1.1400 handle, while GBP/USD is also supported and has returned near the 1.2750 level but with further upside restricted by nearby resistance levels and amid ongoing political uncertainty. There were also comments from leading PM candidate Boris Johnson who suggested the need to prepare for Brexit under WTO rules and that there should be creative ambiguity regarding payment of the EU divorce bill, while he also thinks that he can get a no-deal Brexit through parliament. Elsewhere, the predominantly risk-averse tone has spurred mild flows into safe-haven JPY and antipodeans also took advantage of the USD-woes in early trade with NZD/USD the outperformer after better than expected trade data, although this eventually dragged AUD/NZD below 1.0500 and forced AUD/USD to give back its gains.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are slightly higher with prices partially benefitting from the cautious sentiment and recent gains in T-notes, although upside is limited ahead as focus turns to the 20yr JGB auction later.
